Antimicrobial resistance  
Charles Darwin takes as a basis the fact that all living beings develop further through 
evolutionary pressure. This mechanism allows all living organisms to adapt to living conditions and their changes and thus to secure the preservation of their species.  This given mechanism 
is also followed by bacteria which, as prokaryotes, have a specific cellular structure and corresponding cell components.  In contrast to eukaryotes, however, they do not have a core 
enveloped by a membrane; their DNA is freely present in the cytoplasm as a so -called nuclear 
equivalent . What also differs from higher organisms is that their genetic information can be 
present either only at one or at several locations, and  is also connected to the cytoplasm 
membrane. These structures also carry the genetic information in the bacteria and are called bacterial chromosomes  in analogy to the eukaryotic DNA. In addition, bacteria have so- called 
plasmids, which carry DNA -independ ent genetic information, and bacteria have evolutionary 
advantages, which play a central role, particularly with regard to resistance, multiple resistance, toxin formation and virulence, and code corresponding mechanisms.  
In the submucosa of the host orga nism, bacteria oppose the body's own phagocytic defence 
mechanisms at the phagocytic level.   Here, too, bacteria have developed adaptation 
mechanisms that can circumvent this protection and enable further progression into the 
host.  Mechanisms that include  this are based on an evolutionary development over more than 
4 million years. During this period, bacterial pathogens succeeded in developing survival strategies. A central factor here is the formation of so -called secondary metabolites, which 
represent a defence structure of bacteria. In this case, a distinction is made between symbiotic 
and antagonistic substances, whereby symbionts have a survival advantage through a common 
use of substrates. Antagonists work through toxic metabolites which inhibit the growth of the host organism or lead to its death.  
In particular, the following factors play a central role in the development of antimicrobial 
resistance:  
 - Mutation  
 - Recombination  
 - Selection  
 - Genetic drift  
                                                                                                     
                  
24 
 
In order to  defend themselves against attacks by bacteria, medicinal plants have developed 
ways of defending themselves: mechanical protection 
- Indigestibility of polymeric plant tissues (e.g., cellulose, lignin)  
- Synthesis of antibacterial proteins and enzymes (e. g., lysozyme, nucleases, lectins)  
- Synthesis of secondary substances which are readily available and have an inhibitory effect 
on bacterial metabolic systems  
- Mechanical protection (Melzig, 2020)  
Currently, about 70,000 secondary substances are isolated from plants, which cause a general 
non-specific defence against bacteria. These act in the sense of a mass attack through a 
combined effect of several secondary substances in one and the same medicinal plant or by 
overloading the bacterial structures (Wink, 2015).  
The starting points and effect mechanisms of these plant substances are proteins, biomembranes and nucleic acids.  
- Proteins: plant substances lead to the modification of bacterial proteins, which are essential for the survival of the bacteria: e .g., phenols, sesquiterpenes, aldehydes  
- Biomembranes: a modulation of permeability or destruction of the membrane 
structure of bacteria takes place: e.g., saponins, terpenes, glucosinolates  
- Nucleic acids (DNA/RNA): inhibition of replication, transcription and/or translation and thus multiplication of bacteria takes place: e.g., epoxides, alkaloids, 
furanocoumarins (Melzig, 2020). 
Summary  
Phytotherapy offers a wide range of substances with antimicrobial potential. Target structures 
are central processes of bacterial metabolism in the sense of a mostly unspecific attack and the 
combination of several ingredients, resulting in a broad spectrum effect (Imming et al., 2006).

Galenics  
 
Introd uction  
The use of medicinal plants is as old as mankind itself. Data from the World Health 
Organization (WHO) show that about 80% of the world's population uses medicinal plant -
based products to prevent and treat diseases.  
According to current WHO research , 11% of the 252 basic medicines are plant preparations 
[1]. Herbal proprietary medicinal products are used preventively, for the treatment of mild 
disease manifestations, or as concomitant therapy in treating chronic diseases. The most 
common fields of application include the respiratory tract, the digestive and urogenital tract, 
and mild and moderate forms of anxiety disorders and depression, and also a wide variety of diseases of the skin and mucous membranes. The healing progresses gradually: the greate st 
effect is therefore to be expected 2 –3 weeks after starting the application [ESCOP].  
 
The term "phytotherapy" is derived from the use of herbal drugs and their preparations for 
preventing and treating diseases [Weiss, R. F., Fintelmann, V.: Lehrbuch der Phyotherapie, 8
th 
Ed. Stuttgart: Hyppocrates Verlag Stuttgart, 1997]]. Phytotherapy is part of allopathic medicine and is not one of the so- called "special therapeutic 
disciplines" or an "alternative medicine", such as homeopathy and anthroposophy. In recent 
decades, the term "rational phytotherapy" has been coined based on modern concepts of  the 
use of herbal medicinal products from standardised plant extracts. The quality of the resulting 
products is ensured by the use of quality- tested raw materials, defined preparation processes 
and validated equipment. The quality control of herbal drugs and their preparations (for 
example powders, tinctures, extracts, extracts, juices and essential oils) is carried out in 
accordance with the specifications of Pharmacopoeia and other European regulators.  
Clearly defined parameters can be found in the foll owing plants:  
• Monographs of Pharmacopoeia  
• Monographs by the European Medicines Agency (EMA/EMEA) comprising who 
monographs  
• European Scientific Cooperative on Phythotherapy (ESCOP)  
• Commission E publications  
• National provisions  
                                                                                                     
                  
27 
 
 
The quality control of phytopreparations depends on their pharmaceutical forms. This 
process has strictly defined phases:  
1. Literature and market analysis  
2. Formula composition  
3. Validation of the production process  
4. Quality control of the final product  
5. Compilation of technology and approval -specific documents  
This chapter deals more closely with the process of making herbal preparations, from the 
selection of raw materials to the finished remedies (such as tea, deco cts, drops, syrups, etc.).  
 
The term "galenics" can be traced back to the well -known physician and pharmacist Claudius 
Galen. Galen lived between 129 and 201 AD and worked for a long time during Roman 
campaigns in northern Italy. He is considered the fathe r of galenic pharmacy. His writings on 
the development of complex galenic preparations include 304 medicinal products of plant 
origin. 
Galenics  is the process of converting an active substance into a ready -to-use drug form, which 
can be dosed accordingly. The "galenical formulation" deals with the principles of the 
preparation and composition of medicines in order to achieve optimum absorption. T oday, 
galenic formulation is a branch of pharmacy: the science of creating forms of dosage, which 
have a proven effect on the pharmacokinetics, pharmacodynamics and safety profile of a drug. 
Galenic formulations were produced almost exclusively by squeezing, extract preparation and 
other simple methods. They were widely used for therapeutic purposes until the end of the 15th century.  
 
Nowadays, galenic formulations have been revised with modern concepts and neo -galenic 
drugs have been developed. In the preparation of these products, special highly complex 
technologies are used which are intended to ensure a high bioavailability of the formulations.  
 These medicines are comprised of the following:  
• Active substance in appropriate formulation (as an extract, an isolated natural 
component of a synthetic medicinal product)

• Excipients (ingredients that serve as a means of transport or medium of the formulation, 
for example, diluents, fillers, lubricants, dyes, flavourings or preservatives)  
• Packaging/transport p ackaging (e.g., blisters, bottles, inhaler, ampoules, pre -filled 
syringes)  
 
 
Basic terms related to herbal medicinal products  
This chapter introduces the following basic concepts:  
Monographs, pharmaceutical preparations, herbal drugs, herbal medicinal 
preparations, herbal teas and soluble teas, herbal active ingredient extracts  
A monograph of the pharmaceutical preparations is published in the Phar. Eur. as a reference 
source for standards for active substances, excipients and pharmaceutical forms to be us ed in 
the preparation/manufacturing of medicinal products, but not as a guide to preparation, as there 
are specific guidelines for preparation methods and related controls  
Pharmaceutical preparations are defined as medicines which generally consist of acti ve 
substances which can be combined with excipients that are formulated in a dosage form suitable for the intended use, if appropriate after reconstitution, in a suitable and appropriately 
labelled container. Pharmaceutical preparations may or may not be a uthorised by the competent 
authority and may be tailored to the specific needs of patients in accordance with the legislation. 
Non-authorised pharmaceuticals are stomachic preparations, i.e., pharmaceutical preparations 
which are individually prepared for a specific patient or a specific group of patients and are 
supplied after preparation, and substance preparations, i.e., pharmaceutical preparations which 
are prepared and stored in advance until a delivery request is made.  
If appropriate, pharmaceutical preparations also correspond to the dosage form monographs (e.g., capsules, tablets) and general monographs with regard to herbal teas, tinctures, etc.  
The production/preparation must be carried out within the framework of an appropriate quality system and comply with the relevant standards for the type of product manufactured. Licensed 
products must meet the requirements of their licence. For non- authorised products, a risk 
assessment in accordance with the section "Ethical considerations and guidelines for  the 
preparation of non- authorised pharmaceutical preparations" is of particular importance, as 
these products have not previously been assessed by the competent authority. 
During pharmaceutical development or prior to production/preparation, appropriate 
ingredients, procedures, tests and specifications must be identified and justified in order to                                                                                                     
                  
29 
 
ensure the suitability of the product for the intended purpose. This also includes taking into 
account the required properties in order to determine whether certain ingredient properties or 
process steps are decisive for the required quality of the pharmaceutical preparation.  
Active substances and excipients used in the formulation of pharmaceutical preparations shall meet the requirements of the relevant general monographs, e.g.,  substances for pharmaceutical 
purposes, essential oils, herbal medicinal product extracts, herbal medicinal products, herbal 
medicinal product preparations , etc. The formulation of the pharmaceutical preparation and its 
container must ensure that the microbiological quality is appropriate for the intended use. A suitable container should be selected. The intended use of the preparation, the properties of the  
container, the required shelf life and product/container incompatibilities are taken into account. The stability requirements for pharmaceutical preparations depend on their intended use and the desired storage time. Methods used for the purpose of the st ability test for all relevant 
properties of the preparation are validated as stability indicators, i.e., the methods allow the quantification of the relevant degradation products and changes in physical properties.  
Pharmaceutical preparations which are off ered in unit doses correspond to the test(s) as 
prescribed in the respective monograph of the specific dosage form.  
The relevant labelling requirements in the monographs of the general dosage forms apply. In addition, relevant provisions of the European U nion or other applicable provisions apply. [Eur. 
Pharm. 04/2019:2619 PHARMACEUTICAL PREPARATIONS Pharmaceuticals]  
The European Pharmacopoeia defines herbal medicinal products mainly as whole, fragmented or broken plants or parts of plants in their unproces sed state, usually in dried form, but 
sometimes also fresh. In this general monograph, the word "plant" is used in the broader sense 
to include algae, fungi and lichens. Certain exudates which have not undergone any treatment 
are also considered herbal med icinal products. Herbal medicines are precisely defined by the 
botanical scientific name according to the binomial system (genus, species, variety and author).  
"Whole" describes a herbal drug that has not been reduced in size and is presented as harvested, 
dried or undried; for example: dog rose, bitter fennel or sweet fennel, Roman chamomile 
blossom. Fragmented describes a herbal medicinal product which has been reduced in size after harvesting in order to permit simple handling, drying and/or packaging; f or example: china -
bark, rhubarb, passion flower.  
"Broken" describes a herbal drug in which the more fragile parts of the plant are broken down during drying, packaging or transport; for example: belladonna leaf, matricaria flower, hop strobile.  
"Cut" descr ibes a herbal medicinal product that has been reduced in size other than by 
pulverisation, so that the macroscopic description in the monograph of the herbal medicinal                                                                                                     
                  
30 
 
product can no longer be used. If a herbal drug is cut for a specific purpose that resul ts in the 
cut herbal drug being homogeneous, for example, if it is cut for herbal teas, it is a herbal drug 
preparation. Certain cut herbal medicinal products processed in this way may be the subject of an individual monograph. 
A herbal medicinal product w hich corresponds to its monograph and is subsequently cut for 
extraction shall, in its cut form, with the exception of its macroscopic description, correspond 
to the monograph for that herbal medicinal product, unless justified otherwise. 
  
The term herbal  drug is synonymous with the term herbal substance used in the European 
Community's legislation on herbal medicinal products (EMA).  
 
DRIED HERBAL MEDICINAL PRODUCTS  
- Dried herbal medicinal products are obtained from crops or wild plants. Suitable collecti on, 
cultivation, harvesting, drying, fragmentation and storage conditions are essential to ensure 
their quality.  
Dried herbal medicinal products are as free as possible from contaminants such as soil, dust, 
dirt and other contaminants such as fungi, insect s and other animal contaminants. They didn't 
rot. 
Dried herbal medicinal products are identified on the basis of their macroscopic and 
microscopic descriptions and all other necessary tests (e.g., thin- layer chromatography).  
The tests include: foreign matter (2.8.2); loss on drying (2.2.32; water (2.2.13); pesticides 
(2.8.13); heavy metals (2.4.27); total ash (2.4.16); ash insoluble in hydrochloric acid (2.8.1); extractable matter; swelling index (2.8.4); bitterness value (2.8.15); aflatoxin B1 (2.8.18). If  
necessary, limit values may be prescribed for aflatoxins; ochratoxin A (2.8.22); radioactive contamination; microbial contamination. If a dried herbal medicinal product is used as a whole, cut or powdery as a constituent of a medicinal product, the microbial contamination is checked (5.1.8. Microbiological quality of herbal medicinal products for oral use and extracts used in their preparation or 5.1.4. Microbiological quality of non- sterile pharmaceutical preparations 
and substances for pharmaceutical pur poses (e.g., for cutaneous use)).

FRESH PLANT SUBSTANCES  
A fresh herbal medicinal product is one that is processed into a  herbal medicinal product (e.g., 
essential oil, juice, tincture) within a short time after harvesting. In these circumstances, the 
extensive analysis required for dried herbal medicinal products is not appropriate and the following analytical requirements,  based on the origin of the fresh herbal medicinal product, 
are considered appropriate provided that processing them into herbal medicinal products takes place within a validated period of time after harvesting. Fresh herbal medicinal products may 
be frozen for storage purposes. In order to ensure the quality of the herbal medicinal product, 
defined processes for freezing and thawing are required. Appropriate testing of the herbal 
medicinal product, justified on the basis of freezing and manufacturing proce dures, are carried 
out and may include testing before freezing and at the time of use. When handling and 
processing fresh herbal medicinal products, it is necessary to ensure by visual inspection or 
other suitable means that there is no unwanted fermentation, the presence of which can change the quality of the herbal medicinal product preparation, including a possible production of mycotoxins [Pharm. Eur., 07/2017:1433, HERBAL MEDICINAL PRODUCTS, Plantae 
medicinales]  
 
HERBAL MEDICINAL PREPARATIONS (Plantae medicinales praeparatae)  
Herbal medicinal preparations are homogeneous products which are obtained by 
subjecting herbal medicinal preparations to treatments such as extraction, distillation, 
expression, fractionation, purification, concentration or fermentation. 
  
Herbal medicinal  preparations include, for example, extracts, essential oils, expressed 
juices, processed exudates and herbal medicinal products which have been subjected to 
comminution for certain applications, for example, herbal medicinal products which have been cut for herbal teas or powdered in order to be put into capsules. 
The term "commercialised" used in European Community legislation on herbal 
medicinal products describes a herbal medicinal product which has been either cut or powdered. [Eur. Pharm., 07/2010:1434, HERBAL MEDICINAL PREPARATIONS, Plantae medicinales praeparatae]  
The term herbal medicinal preparation is synonymous with the term herbal preparation 
used in European Community legislation on herbal medicinal products.

HERBAL INGREDIENT EXTRACTS (Plantarum medicinalium extracta)  
Herbal medicinal extracts are liquid (liquid extraction preparations), semi -solid (soft 
extracts and oleoresins) or solid (dry extracts) preparations which are obtained from herbal 
pharmaceuticals (1433) using suitable solvents [Pharm. Eur. 04/2019:0765; H ERBAL DRUG 
EXTRACTS; Plantarum medicinalium extracta]. An extract is essentially defined by the quality of the herbal medicinal product, by its production process (extraction solvent, processing method, etc.) and by its specifications.  
The monographs of the European Pharmacopoeia for extracts include the true (native) 
extract and, where present, the excipients.  
Different types of extracts can be distinguished. 
Standardised extracts  are adapted to a defined content of one or more constituents 
with known ther apeutic activity. This is achieved by adapting the extract with inert auxiliaries 
or by mixing batches of the extract. 
Quantified extracts  are adapted to one or more active markers whose content is 
controlled within a limited, defined range. Adjustments ar e made by mixing batches of the 
extract.                                                                                                      
                  
34 
 
Other extracts  are not adapted to a certain content of constituents. For control 
purposes, one or more constituents are used as analytical markers. The minimum content for 
these analytical markers is given in an individual monograph.  
Various batches of the herbal medicinal product which correspond to the relevant 
monograph, or in the absence of an individual monograph with other suitable specifications, 
can be combined before extraction, for example, in order to reac h the quantity of herbal 
medicinal product required for the production process, or in the case of standardised and 
quantified extracts to reach a certain content range for one or more constituents of the herbal 
medicinal product to be extracted. The herbal  medicine can also be subjected to pretreatment, 
for example, grinding, inactivation of enzymes or degreasing. In addition, undesirable 
constituents (e.g.,  toxic constituents) or undesirable substances (e.g., insoluble substances) can be removed at a suit able stage of the production process. Water used for the production of 
extracts meets the requirements of the monograph Water for the Production of Extracts (2249).  
  
For technological reasons, suitable excipients can be added in various phases of the 
preparation process (for example, as part of the drying process or to improve the homogeneity 
or consistency of an extract). For standardised extracts, it is also possible to add suitable inert 
excipients in order to adapt one or more constituents to a defined content. In the case of 
quantified extracts and "other" extracts, the addition of inert excipients to adjust the content of constituents tested is not permitted. Excipients are only absorbed for technological reasons and the manufacturer must indicate the  content of these excipients as a fixed percentage. In some 
applications, an excipient may be added in a narrow percentage range (e.g., silicon dioxide 
between 0.1 and 0.5 percent to improve the flowability of the extract). The proposed range 
must be justified by the manufacturer. Suitable stabilisers, antioxidants and antimicrobial preservatives may be added to the extracts, where justified and permitted.  
The tests include microbiological quality (5.1.4 or 5.1.8), heavy metals (2.4.27), 
aflatoxins (2.8.18) , ochratoxin A (2.8.22) and pesticide residues (2.8.13). If a heavy metal test 
is carried out, extracts are subject to the same heavy metal limits as in the monograph Herbal Medicinal Products (1433), unless otherwise stated in a single extract monograph or unless otherwise justified and permitted.  
The label states: the herbal drug used; where appropriate, this fresh herbal medicinal 
product has been used; the form of the extract (e.g., liquid, tincture, soft, oleoresin or dry); where appropriate, that the extract is standardised or quantified; in the case of standardised extracts, the defined content of constituents with known therapeutic effect; in the case of quantified extracts, the range of active markers indicated; where appropriate, that the extract i s 
"refined"; the first solvent or solvents used for the extraction (e.g., ethanol 60% v/v); the name                                                                                                     
                  
35 
 
and quantity of the excipients contained in the extract (e.g., diluents, stabilisers, antimicrobial 
preservatives, antioxidants); in the case of quantified extracts and "other" extracts, the ratio of 
the quantity of herbal medicinal products to the quantity of true (native) extract, expressed on a mass basis for soft extracts, oleoresins and dry extracts and either on a mass or mass volume basis for liquid e xtraction preparations; where appropriate, the percentage of dry residues; the 
storage conditions. 
  
Liquid extraction preparations – Praeparationes fluidae ab extractione  
Liquid extracts – Extracta Fluida  
Quantified liquid (liquid) extracts and "other" liquid (liquid) extracts are liquid 
extraction preparations, of which in general 1 part of the mass or volume corresponds to 1 
part of the mass of the dried herbal medicinal product. Standardised liquid (liquid) extracts are only defined by their content of constituents with known therapeutic activity.  
Liquid extracts are prepared using ethanol in a suitable concentration and/or water 
together with any other substances (e.g.,  glycerol  or ammonia solution) to extract the herbal 
medicinal product, or by dissolving a soft or dry extract of the herbal medicinal product (prepared using the same extraction solvent that would be used to prepare the liquid extract by direct extraction) in etha nol of the required concentration or water.  
  
If the liquid extract contains ethanol, it is tested for 2 -propanol (2.9.11) with a 
maximum content of 0.05% v/v, unless compliance with this limit is ensured by accurate 
knowledge of the ethanol supply chain a nd the production process of the extract.  
With the exception of standardised liquid extracts, liquid extracts prepared from soft 
or dry extracts contain no excipients other than those which would be present in the liquid 
extract prepared by direct extracti on. However, exceptions may be justified in certain cases, 
for example, where the soft extract used to prepare the liquid extract contains stabilisers, 
antioxidants or antimicrobial preservatives added to ensure its stability. 
Liquid extracts are adjusted,  if necessary, in such a way that they meet the 
requirements for the content of solvent. Liquid extracts can be filtered if necessary.  
A light sediment can form when left standing.  
The tests include the relative density (2.2.5); ethanol (2.9.10); methanol (2.9.11); dry 
residue (2.8.16). Where appropriate, the liquid extract complies with the prescribed limits. 
In addition to the requirements listed above, the label indicates the ethanol content, if 
appropriate in percent v/v. 
                                                                                                      
                  
36 
 
Tinctures – Tinkturae  
Quantif ied tinctures and "other" tinctures are liquid extraction preparations which 
obtain either 1 part of the mass of the herbal medicinal product and 10 parts of the mass or 
volume of the extraction solvent or 1 part of the mass of the herbal medicinal product  and 5 
parts of the mass or volume of the extraction solvent. Alternatively, they can be obtained either using 1 part mass of herbal medicinal products and sufficient extraction solvent to prepare 10 parts by mass or volume of the tincture or 1 part mass of herbal medicinal products and sufficient extraction solvent to prepare 5 parts by mass or volume of the tincture. Other herbal medicinal product to extraction solvent ratios can be used. 
Standardised tinctures are only defined by their content of constit uents with a known 
therapeutic effect.  
Tinctures are generally produced either by maceration or percolation using ethanol in 
an appropriate concentration to extract the herbal medicinal product or by dissolving a soft or dry extract of the herbal medicinal  product (which has been produced using the same 
extraction solvent that would be used to produce the tincture by direct extraction) in ethanol of the required concentration. 
With the exception of standardised tinctures, tinctures prepared from soft or dry 
extracts contain no excipients other than those which would be present in the tincture prepared by direct extraction. However, exceptions may be justified in certain cases, for example, where the soft extract used to produce the tincture contains stabilis ers, antioxidants 
or antimicrobial preservatives added to ensure its stability.  
  
If necessary, tinctures are adjusted in such a way that they meet the requirements for 
the content of solvent. Tinctures can be filtered if necessary. Tinctures are usually 
transparent. A light sediment can form when left standing. 
The tincture is tested for 2 -propanol (2.9.11); relative density (2.2.5); ethanol (2.9.10); 
methanol (2.9.11); dry residue (2.8.16).  
In addition to the requirements listed above, the label indicate s the ethanol content in 
percent v/v.  
  
  
Soft extracts – Extracta spissa  
Soft extracts are semi -solid preparations which are obtained by evaporation or partial 
evaporation of the solvent used for the preparation.                                                                                                     
                  
37 
 
The tests include: dry residues (2.8.16); residues of solvents controlled in accordance 
with Chapter 5.4, unless otherwise specified or justified and permitted.  
  
Oleoresins – Oleoresina  
Oleoresins are semi -solid extracts which consist of a resin in solution in an essential 
and/or fatty oil and are obtained by evaporation of the solvents used for their preparation. 
This monograph applies to oleoresins produced by extraction and not to natural oleoresins.  
The tests include: water (2.2.13); residues of solvents controlled in accordance with 
Chapter  5.4, unless otherwise specified or justified and permitted.  
  
Dry extracts – Extracta Sicca  
Dry extracts are solid preparations which are obtained by evaporation of the solvent 
used for their preparation. Dry extracts usually have a loss on drying of not more than 5 per cent m/m. If this is justified and permitted, a loss on drying with a different limit value or a test for water may be prescribed.  
The tests include: loss on drying (2.8.17); water (2.5.12); residues of solvents 
controlled in accordance wit h Chapter 5.4, unless otherwise specified or justified and 
permitted.  
 
 
 
European HMP Regulations  
The European Medicines Agency provides guidance on the quality of herbal medicinal 
products, the WHO provides guidance on standards and guidelines for good a gricultural 
practice, and good laboratory practices. The development of new, sophisticated analytical and 
technological methods and processes for the development and characterisation of extractive 
isolate has considerably improved the quality of the final herbal products. On the other hand, the process of harmonising the quality system for the production and management of herbal medicinal products exists in many countries. But more efforts are needed globally to revitalise 
the prescribed directives and regulations in practice. The main objective of the Herbal 
Medicinal Product Committee (HPMC) is to establish a detailed list of monographs and processed herbal substances and preparations that are in medical use long enough so that there is no harm in using them under normal conditions. The monograph contains the Committee's 
professional opinion on a particular plant product on the basis of scientific data or traditional                                                                                                     
                  
38 
 
use in the European Union (EU). For each plant, the substances, indications, speed, use and 
other relevant data on their safe use or their composition, are given. The list and versions of 
the monographs are available for public consultation. In Europe, companies can apply for three different types of market approvals for a herbal medicinal product (HMP):  
1. Full implementation. The manufacturer of a herbal medicinal product must provide 
documentation showing its efficacy and safety and the studies must be identical to those submitted for registration of a synthetic medicinal product. 
2. Well established use. The manufacturer of a herbal medicinal product may be 
allowed to register themselves on the basis of submitted detailed scientific literature showing that the herbal medicinal product has been used for medicinal purposes in Europe for at least  
10 years and has a recognised level of efficacy and safety.  
3. Traditional use. The efficacy and safety of a herbal medicinal product can be accepted 
on the basis of many years of experience. Herbal remedies can be registered if the documents prove that t hey can be used to alleviate certain illnesses, but not less than 30 years, with at least 
15 years in Europe.  
The registration process for herbal medicinal products at all levels of the European 
Union (EU) is carried out in accordance with European Directi ve 2004/24/EC, which 
introduces simplified but strictly defined procedures and includes the harmonisation of existing national legislation. Regarding registration in non- EU countries, a limited number of herbal 
medicinal products have been registered, despite the efforts made in the framework of national 
legislation and harmonisation in larger systems. Therefore, the identification of problems and discrepancies and the systematic plan to overcome them pose a major challenge to the presence of these herbal m edicines on the EU market.

Quality and quality control of extracts  
The extracts are one of the most frequently used herbal preparations. The extracts may 
have a liquid, semi -solid or solid consistency. They are most commonly produced from dried 
and granular plant material. Different processes can be used for extract production: maceration, 
percolation, extraction of the continuous and so on. Nowadays, the process of obtaining plant 
material through supercritical fluids is increasingly used. Tinctures are extractive products 
normally obtained by the method of maceration.

If a herbal remedy is a mixture of plant extracts or tinctures, it is usually difficult to 
carry out the quantitative analysis of the active ingredients for each individual extract. For these

preparations, the content analysis of the active compounds for which the preparation is declared 
is carried out (LC, UV -Vis spectroscopy, GC and GC -MS spectrometry, infrared (IR), nuclear 
magnetic resonance (NMR), etc.). In addition, a manufacturer shall, in principle, include the 
typical fingerprint of the chromatogram, spectrum or othe r physical parameter of the 
preparation constituent, which may be used by a control laboratory for identification. This 
approach can also be used for the quantitative analysis of the preparation.  
Semi -solid forms (herbal gel, cream and ointment) are checked for authentication, 
filling, pH and microbiological purity. In the case of fixed- dose pharmaceutical forms 
(capsules, tablets, etc.), a control is carried out for each individual dose. The control for these 
forms of herbal remedies includes the authenti cation, the appearance, the indicated weight of 
the package or the individual dose of the preparation. Qualitative and quantitative analyses of 
the declared active substances or of a marker compound of the preparation are mandatory. For 
this analysis, similar (or correspondingly modified) methods are used for the analysis of herbal medicinal products or extractive preparations (if not according to the pharmacopoeia, these methods must be validated by the CPMP/ICH/281/95). 
 
Monitoring the stability  of the phytopreparation  
Medicinal herbs and products based on medicinal herbs react very sensitively to 
external influences -  the presence of elevated temperatures, moisture and direct light. They are 
susceptible to reactions of oxidation, degradation, hydrolysis a nd evaporation, so that in the 
production of herbal remedies special attention must be paid to a number of factors which can influence the quality of the end product. In order to determine the stability of a product, to 
define storage conditions and shelf life, stability tests are carried out, which include the 
examination of the environmental factors that affect the change in the quality of the final product. Stability tests are carried out at various stages of development and production. During the study period, the first stress test is conducted to select the optimal, most compatible 
excipients and the best formulation. All raw materials, adjuvants, active ingredients and 
extraction products used are subject to stability testing and shelf life definition, for suitable 
packaging and under certain environmental conditions. Stability is defined as the period during which the product remains within the specified quality limits of the prescribed specification. In 
accordance with the requirements of the EMEA, various specific stability tests are carried out 
for different herbs.

Simple preparations of substances of plant or animal origin include: infusions (Infusa) 
and decoctions (Decocta).  
Infusions and decoctions are always produced from plant substances by infusion. There 
are water infusions in cold and boiling water. A cold infusion is obtained by infusing the plant 
substance in distilled water at room temperature for 4 hours; hot infusion - by pouring a herbal 
preparation with boiling distilled water and immersing the vessel in a steam bath for 5 m.  
In general, formulations include:  
·         Solids (tablets, capsules, bags, etc.)  
·         liquids (suspensions, solutions, syrups, etc.). 
·         Semi -solid (gels, creams, ointments, etc.).  
In practice, the following preparations are used for the respiratory tract:  
Ø Oral liquid preparations (syrups, powders and granules for syrups, solutions, 
emulsions, suspensions, powder solutions or suspensions, drops, powder for drops).  
Ø Solid preparation for oral use (powder, granules, capsules, tablets, sachet)  
Ø Semi -solid preparations for cutaneous application (ointments, creams, pastes, 
cataplasms, medical patches, hydrophilic and lipophilic gels)  
Ø Nose and ear preparations.  
Ø Neogalenic preparations

. Requirement: “Liquid Preparations for Oral 
Administration” are usually solutions, emulsions or suspensions which contain one or more 
active ingredients in a suitable vehicle; however, they may consist of liquid active ingredients which are used as such (oral liquids). Some oral preparations are prepared by diluting 
concentrated liquid preparations or powders or granules to for m oral solutions or suspensions, 
drops or syrups using a suitable vehicle.  
The vehicle for each oral preparation shall be selected taking into account the nature of 
the active substance (s) and the organoleptic properties appropriate to the intended use of  the 
preparation. Liquid preparations for oral use may contain suitable antimicrobial preservatives,

antioxidants and other adjuvants such as dispersing, suspending, thickening, emulsifying, 
buffering, wetting, solubilising, stabilising, flavouring and swe etening agents and colouring

separation, but are readily redispersed on shaking. Suspensions can have a sediment which is readily dispersed during shaking in order to obtain a suspension which remains sufficiently 
stable to be able to deliver the correct dose.

The name of the preservative added is indicated on the label.  
  
 Oral solutions, emulsions and suspensions  
Oral solutions, emulsions and suspensions are supplied in single -dose or multiple -dose 
containers. Each dose from a multidose container  is administered by means of an apparatus 
suitable for measuring the prescribed volume. The device is usually a spoon or cup for volumes 
of 5 ml or a multiple thereof or an oral syringe for other volumes. 
  
- Powders and granules for oral solutions and suspensions  
Powders and granules for the preparation of oral solutions or suspensions should be 
reconstituted with the prescribed liquid in order to prepare a liquid preparation for oral 
administration. They may contain auxiliaries, in partic ular in order to facilitate spreading or 
dissolution and to prevent caking.

After dissolution or suspension, they meet the requirements for oral solutions or for oral 
suspensions. 
The tests include: uniformity of dosage units; uniformity of contents; uni formity of 
mass.  
The label indicates the method of preparation of the solution or suspension and the 
conditions and duration of storage after reconstitution. 
  
 
Drops for ingestion  
Oral drops are solutions, emulsions or suspensions which are administered in small 
amounts such as drops by means of a suitable device. The label indicates the number of drops 
per millilitre of preparation or per gram of preparation when the dose is measured in drops. 
  
Powder for oral drops  
Powders for the preparation of oral drops should be reconstituted with the prescribed 
liquid in order to prepare a liquid preparation for oral administration. They may contain excipients to facilitate dissolution or suspension in the prescribed liquid or t o prevent caking. 
After dissolution or suspension, they meet the requirements for oral drops.  
The tests include: uniformity of dosage units; uniformity of contents; uniformity of 
mass.  
  
Syrup 
Syrups are aqueous preparations which are distinguished by a s weet taste and a viscous 
consistency. They may contain sucrose in a concentration of at least 45 % m/m. The sweet taste can also be obtained by using other polyols or sweeteners. Syrups generally contain aromatic or other flavouring substances. Each dose f rom a multidose container is administered by means 
of an apparatus suitable for measuring the prescribed volume. The device is usually a spoon or cup for volumes of 5 ml or a multiple thereof.  
The label indicates the name and concentration of the polyol or  sweetener.  
  
                                                                                                     
                  
47 
 
- Powders and granules for syrups  
Powders and granules for syrups should be reconstituted with the prescribed liquid to 
produce a liquid preparation for oral administration. They may contain excipients to facilitate 
dissolution.  
After dissol ution, they meet the requirements for syrups. 
(Pharm. Eur. 01/2018:0672, ORAL LIQUID PREPARATIONS, preparationes liquidae 
peroraliae)  
 
Solid preparation for oral use  
Oral powder  
According to Pharm. Eur. 10. Requirement: oral powders are preparations consisting of solid, 
loose, dry particles of varying fineness. They contain one or more active substances, with or without adjuvants, and, where necessary, colours and flavourings appr oved by the competent 
authority. They are generally administered in or with water or another suitable liquid. They can 
also be swallowed directly. They are available as single- dose or multiple -dose preparations. 
Multi- dose oral powders require the provision of a measuring instrument capable of delivering 
the prescribed quantity. Each dose of a single -dose powder is enclosed in a single container, 
for example a pouch or a vial.  
The tests include: uniformity of dosage units; uniformity of contents; uniformit y of 
mass; uniformity of mass of doses dispensed from multi -dose containers.  
If the preparation contains volatile substances or if the contents need to be protected, 
stored in an airtight container. 
  
Effervescent powder  
Effervescent powders are presented  as single -dose or multiple -dose preparations and 
generally contain acidic substances and carbonates or hydrogen carbonates which react rapidly in the presence of water in order to release carbon dioxide. They are intended to be dissolved 
or dispersed in w ater before administration. Unless otherwise justified and authorised, the 
preparation conforms to the disintegration test.  (Pharm Eur, 01/2020:1165, POWDER, ORAL, powder peroral)  
 
                                                                                                      
                  
48 
 
Granules  
Granules are preparations which consist of solid, dry additive s of powder particles 
which are robust enough to withstand handling. They are intended for oral administration. 
Some are swallowed as such, some are chewed and some are dissolved or dispersed in water or other suitable liquid before administration. 
For rea sons of patient safety and to ensure the correct administration of the medication, 
this term can also be used if very small tablets (instead of granules) are contained in a bag and if the entire contents of the bag are intended for oral administration as a  single dose.  
Granules contain one or more active substances, with or without adjuvants, and, where 
necessary, colours and flavourings approved by the competent authority.  
Granules are available as single- dose or multiple -dose preparations. Each dose of a 
multi- dose preparation is administered by means of an apparatus suitable for measuring the 
prescribed amount. In the case of single -dose granules, each dose is enclosed in a single 
container, for example a bag or a vial.  
  
Where relevant, containers for gr anules meet the requirements of the materials (3.1 and 
subsections) and containers (3.2 and subsections) used for the manufacture of containers.  
Several categories of granules can be distinguished:  
- effervescent granules;  
– coated granules;  
– gastro -resistant granules;  
- pellets with modified release.  
    
Effervescent granules  
Effervescent granules are uncoated granules which generally contain acidic substances 
and carbonates or bicarbonates which react rapidly in the presence of water in order to liberate 
carbon dioxide. They are intended to be dissolved or dispersed in water before administration. 
  
                                                                                                     
                  
49 
 
Coated granules  
Coated granules are generally multi -dose preparations and consist of granules which 
are coated with one or more layers of mixtures of various auxiliaries.  
 
Pellets with modified release  
Granules with modified release are coated or uncoated granules which contain special 
auxiliaries or are prepared by special processes or both in order to change the rate, the location 
or the t ime at which the active compound or compounds are released. Modified release granules 
are comprised of sustained release granules and sustained release granules.  
 
  Gastroresistant granules  
Gastroresistant granules are sustained release granules intended t o resist gastric fluid 
and to release the active substance(s) into the intestinal fluid. These properties are achieved by 
covering the granules with a gastric -resistant material or in another suitable manner.  
  
Capsules   
Capsules are solid preparations wi th hard or soft shells of various forms and capacities 
which contain a single dose of active compound(s). They are usually intended for oral administration. The capsule shells consist of gelatin or other substances whose consistency can be adapted by adding substances such as glycerol or sorbitol. Excipients such as surfactants, 
opaque fillers, antimicrobial preservatives, sweeteners, dyes and flavourings authorised by the 
competent authority may be added. The capsules may carry surface markings. 
The conten ts of capsules can be solid, semi -solid or liquid. They consist of one or more 
active compounds with or without auxiliaries, such as solvents, diluents, lubricants and 
decomposition agents. The contents do not cause any deterioration of the shell. However, the 
shell is attacked by the digestive fluids and the contents are released.  
  
Several categories of capsules can be distinguished:  
– hard capsules;                                                                                                      
                  
50 
 
– soft capsules;  
– gastro -resistant capsules:  
- capsules with modified release;  
- stamps.  
Capsules conform  to the uniformity of dosage units test or, where justified and 
authorised, to the homogeneity of content and/or homogeneity of mass tests listed below. 
Herbal medicinal products and herbal medicinal preparations in the pharmaceutical form are 
not subject to the provisions of this paragraph.  
Uniformity of content: unless otherwise prescribed or justified and authorised, capsules 
with an active substance content of less than 2 mg or less than 2% of the filling mass of test B 
correspond to the uniformity of t he content of single -dose preparations. Where the preparation 
contains more than one active substance, the requirement shall apply only to those constituents which comply with the abovementioned conditions. 
Uniformity of the mass: the capsules correspond t o the test for uniformity of the mass 
of single -dose preparations. If the content uniformity test is required for all active substances, 
the mass uniformity test is not required.  
Unless otherwise justified and authorised, an appropriate dissolution test for solid 
dosage forms is required. If a dissolution test is required, a disintegration test may not be 
required.  
The name of the preservative added is indicated on the label.  
Hard capsules  are solid single -dose preparations. They consist of a hard shell whose 
capacity can be varied and which contains a solid, semi -solid or liquid preparation. The shell 
consists of gelatin or other substances and consists of 2 prefabricated cylindrical secti ons which 
are open at one end and rounded and closed at the other end. The contents are filled into one 
of the sections and the capsule is closed by pushing the other section over it. 
The active ingredients, as a rule in solid form (powder or granules), ar e introduced into 
one of the sections, which is then closed by pushing the other section over it. The safety of the closure can be increased by suitable means. Hard capsules correspond to the disintegration test.  
Soft capsules  are solid single -dose prepar ations which consist of a soft shell whose 
capacity and shape can be varied and which contain a semi -solid or liquid preparation. The 
shell consists of gelatin or other substances and may contain one or more solid active ingredients. The shell is generally thicker than that of a hard capsule and consists of one part, 
since soft capsules are generally shaped, filled and sealed in a single operation. Soft capsules are usually shaped, filled and sealed in a single operation, but the shell can be prefabricated for                                                                                                     
                  
51 
 
spontaneous use. The shell material may contain an active substance. Liquids can be enclosed 
directly; solids are usually dissolved or dispersed in a suitable vehicle in order to obtain a 
solution or dispersion of pasty consistency.  
  
  
Tablets  
Tablets are solid preparations which each contain a single dose of one or more active 
compounds. They are obtained by compacting uniform particle volumes or by another suitable 
production process, such as extrusion, shaping or freeze -drying (lyophilisation). Tablets are 
intended for oral administration. Some are swallowed whole, some after chewing, some are dissolved or dispersed in water before administration and some are retained in the mouth where the active ingredient is released. The particles consist of one or more active substances, with or without adjuvants, such as diluents, binders, decomposing agents, lubricants, lubricants, substances liable to modify the behaviour of the preparation in the digestive tract, dyes and 
flavourings approved by the competent authority. Tablets are generally straight, solid cylinders 
whose end faces are flat or convex and whose edges can be slanted. They may have scoring marks and bear a symbol or other markings. Tablets can be coated.  
Several categories of oral tablets  can be distinguished:  
– uncoated tablets;  
– coated tablets;  
– enteric- coated tablets;  
- modified -release tablets;  
– effervescent tablets;  
- soluble tablets; 
- dispersible tablets; 
– melting tablets;  
– chewable tablets;  
- oral lyophilisates.  
Tablets are no rmally produced by compressing uniform volumes of particles or particle 
aggregates produced by granulation processes. In the production of tablets, measures are taken 
to ensure that they have a suitable mechanical strength in order to avoid crumbling or br eaking                                                                                                     
                  
52 
 
during handling or subsequent processing. This can be demonstrated by testing the brittleness 
of uncoated tablets and the crush strength of tablets. 
Uncoated tablets comprise single -layer tablets which result from a single compression 
of particles , and multilayer tablets which consist of concentric or parallel layers which are 
obtained by successive compression of particles of different composition. The excipients used are not specifically intended to alter the release of the active compound in the digestive fluids. 
Uncoated tablets correspond to the general definition of tablets. A broken section, when examined under a lens, shows either a uniform texture (single -layer tablets) or a layered texture 
(multilayer tablets), but no signs of coating. Test:  Disintegration.  
Coated tablets are tablets which are covered with one or more layers of mixtures of 
various substances such as natural or synthetic resins, gums, gelatin, inactive and insoluble fillers, sugars, plasticizers, polyols, waxes, dyes approved by the competent authority and sometimes flavourings and active ingredients. The substances used as coatings are normally applied as a solution or suspension under conditions in which the vehicle evaporates. If the 
coating is a very thin polymeric coating, the tablets are referred to as film -coated tablets. Coated 
tablets have a smooth surface, which is often coloured and can be polished; a broken section, 
when examined under a lens, shows a core surrounded by one or more continuous layers of a different te xture. In justified cases, the uniformity of the mass or the content of coated tablets 
other than film -coated tablets can be ensured by checking the cores. Film -coated tablets 
correspond to the disintegration test. 
  
  
OROMUCOUS PREPARATIONS  
Oromucous pre parations are solid, semi -solid or liquid preparations which contain one 
or more active substances which are intended for administration into the oral cavity and/or the throat in order to achieve a local or systemic action. Preparations which are intended for local 
action can be designed for use at a specific point within the oral cavity, such as the gums (gum 
preparations) or the throat (oropharyngeal preparations). Preparations intended for systemic 
action are designed to be absorbed primarily at one or m ore sites of the oral mucosa (e.g., 
sublingual preparations). Mucoadhesive preparations are intended to be retained in the oral 
cavity by adhesion to the mucosal epithelium and can modify the systemic drug absorption at 
the application site. In many oromuc ous preparations, it is likely that a certain part of the active 
ingredient(s) is swallowed and can be absorbed via the gastrointestinal tract. 
 Oromucous preparations can contain suitable antimicrobial preservatives and other 
auxiliaries, such as dispersi ng, suspending, thickening, emulsifying, buffering, wetting,                                                                                                     
                  
53 
 
besolubilising, stabilising, flavouring and sweetening agents. Solid preparations may 
additionally contain lubricants, lubricants and auxiliaries which are suitable for modifying the 
release of t he active compound(s).  
Several categories of preparations for the use of the oral cavity can be distinguished:  
- gargling preparations;  
- mouthwash;  
- gum solutions;  
- oromucous solutions and suspensions;  
- semi -solid oromucous  preparations (including, for example, gum gel, gum paste, 
oromocosal gel, oromocose paste);  
- oromucous drops, sprays and sublingual sprays (including oropharyngeal sprays);  
- lozenges and pastilles;  
- compressed lozenges;  
- sublingual and buccal tablets;  
- oromucous capsules;  
- mucoadhesive preparations;  
- melting films.  
  
  
Gargling preparations  
Gargling preparations are aqueous solutions intended for gargling to achieve a local 
effect. They must not be swallowed. They are supplied as ready -to-use soluti ons or 
concentrated solutions for dilution. They can also be prepared from powders or tablets which 
are dissolved in water before use.  
Gargling preparations may contain adjuvants to adjust the pH to as neutral a value as 
possible. 
  
                                                                                                        
                  
54 
 
Mouthwash 
Mouthwash is an aqueous solution intended to come into contact with the mucosa of 
the oral cavity. They must not be swallowed. They are supplied as ready- to-use solutions or 
concentrated solutions for dilution. They can also be prepared from powders or tablets which 
are dissolved in water before use. Mouthwash may contain adjuvants to adjust the pH to as 
neutral a value as possible.  
  
Gum solutions  
Gum solutions are liquid, generally multi -dose preparations which are intended for 
administration into the gum s by means of a suitable applicator. Oromocose solutions and 
oromucous suspensions.  Oromocose solutions and oromucous suspensions are liquid 
preparations which are intended for administration into the oral cavity by means of a suitable applicator.  Oromoc ous suspensions can have a sediment which is readily dispersible on 
shaking in order to obtain a suspension which remains sufficiently stable to provide the correct 
dose. 
  
  
Semi -solid oromucous preparations  
Semi -solid oromucous  preparations are hydrophilic gels, creams, ointments or pastes 
which are intended for administration into the oral cavity or into a specific part of the oral 
cavity, such as the gums (gum gel, gum cream, gum ointment, gum paste). They can be 
provided as s ingle -dose preparations. Semi -solid oromucous preparations meet the 
requirements of the Semi -Solid Preparations for Cutaneous Use monograph.  
  
Oromucous drops, oromucous  sprays and sublingual sprays   
Oromocosis drops, oromucous sprays and sublingual sprays are solutions, emulsions or 
suspensions which are intended for local or systemic action. They are applied by dripping or 
spraying into the oral cavity or onto a certain part of the oral cavity, such as spraying under the tongue (sublingual spray) or into the throat (oropharyngeal spray). Emulsions may show signs 
of phase separation, but are readily redispersed on shaking. Suspensions can have a sediment 
which is readily dispersed during shaking in order to obtain a suspension which remains sufficiently stable to be able to deliver the correct dose. Liquid oromucous sprays are supplied                                                                                                     
                  
55 
 
in containers with atomising devices or in pressure containers with a suitable adapter with or 
without dosing dose valve, which correspond to the requirements of the Pressuri sed 
Pharmaceutical Preparations monograph. The size of the droplets of the spray is such that their 
deposition in the oral cavity or in the throat is localised as intended.  
  
 
Lozenges and pastilles  
Lozenges and pastilles are solid single -dose preparations  which are intended to be 
aspirated in order to achieve a local effect in the oral cavity and throat. They contain one or 
more active ingredients, usually in a flavoured and sweetened base, and are intended to dissolve 
or dissolve slowly in the mouth during sucking. Lozenges are hard preparations made by moulding. Pastilles are soft, flexible preparations which are prepared by shaping mixtures which contain natural or synthetic polymers or chewing gums and sweeteners.  
  
Compressed lozenges  
Compressed lozenges are solid single -dose preparations which are intended to be 
aspirated in order to achieve a local or systemic effect. They are produced by compression and often have a diamond shape. Compressed lozenges correspond to the general definition of 
tablets.  
 
 Sublingual and buccal tablets  
Sublingual tablets and buccal tablets are solid single -dose preparations that are applied 
under the tongue or to the cheek cavity in order to achieve a systemic effect. They are prepared 
by compression of powder mixtures or g ranulations to give tablets in a  form suitable for the 
intended use. Sublingual tablets and buccal tablets correspond to the general definition 
of tablets.  
 
Oromocose capsules  
 Oromocose capsules are soft capsules that can be chewed or sucked.  
  
                                                                                                     
                  
56 
 
Mucoadhes ive preparations  
Mucoadhesive preparations comprise one or more active compounds which are 
intended to be absorbed systemically through the cheek mucosa over a prolonged period of 
time. They can be supplied as mucoadhesive buccal tablets, as cheek mucosa f ilms or as other 
mucoadhesive solid or semi -solid preparations. They generally contain hydrophilic polymers 
which, on wetting with the saliva, produce a hydrogel which adheres to the cheek mucosa. In addition, buccal films may dissolve. 
Mucoadhesive buccal  tablets are produced by compression and can be single -layer or 
multilayer tablets. Bucccal films are single -layer or multilayer layers of suitable materials.  
In the production of mucoadhesive buccal cold tablets and cheek mucosa films, 
measures are taken to ensure that they have a suitable mechanical strength in order to withstand handling without crumbling or breaking. In the case of mucoadhesive buccal cold tablets, this can be demonstrated by examining the brittleness of uncoated tablets and the resista nce to 
comminution of tablets.  
  
Melting films  
 Melting films are single -layer or multilayer layers of suitable materials which are 
placed in the mouth where they spread rapidly.  
  
Semi -solid preparations for cutaneous use  (Praeparationes molles ad usum dermicum)  
Semi -solid preparations for cutaneous use are intended for the local or transdermal 
release of active compounds or for their softening or protective action. They are homogeneous 
in appearance. Semi -solid preparations for cutaneous application consist of a simple or 
composite base in which usua lly 1 or more active compounds are dissolved or dispersed. 
Depending on the composition, the base can influence the activity of the preparation. The base 
may consist of natural or synthetic substances and may be single -phase or multiphase. 
Depending on the  nature of the base, the preparation may have hydrophilic or hydrophobic 
properties. It may contain suitable auxiliaries, such as antimicrobial preservatives, antioxidants, stabilisers, emulsifiers, thickeners and penetration enhancers. Semi -solid preparat ions for 
cutaneous use, which are intended for use on severely injured skin, are sterile. 
Several categories of semi -solid preparations for cutaneous use can be distinguished:  
- ointments; 
- creams;                                                                                                      
                  
57 
 
- gels;  
- pastes;  
- envelopes;  
- medical wound dressings;  
- cutaneous patches.  
Due to their structure, ointments, creams and gels generally show viscoelastic 
behaviour and are non- Newtonian in character, e.g., plastic, pseudoplastic or thixotropic flow 
at high shear rates. Pastes often have a dilatancy.  
  
Tests:  Uniformity of dosage units; Uniformity of content. 
  
Ointments  
An ointment consists of a single -phase base in which solids or liquids can be dispersed.  
Hydrophobic ointments can only absorb small amounts of water. Typical bases which 
are used for their fo rmulation are hard, liquid and light liquid paraffins, vegetable oils, animal 
fats, synthetic glycerides, waxes and liquid polyalkylsiloxanes.  
Water -emulsifying ointments can absorb relatively large amounts of water and thus 
produce water -in-oil or oil -in-water emulsions after the homogenisation, depending on the 
nature of the emulsifiers: water -in-oil emulsifiers such as wool alcohols, sorbitan esters,  
monoglycerides and fatty alcohols or oil -in-water emulsifiers such as sulfated fatty alcohols, 
polysorbates, macrogol, cetostearyl ethers or esters of fatty acids with macrogols can be used 
for this purpose. Their bases are those of hydrophobic ointments. 
Hydrophilic ointments are preparations with bases which are miscible with water. The 
bases generally co nsist of mixtures of liquid and solid substances (polyethylene glycols). They 
may contain appropriate amounts of water.  
  
Creams  
Creams are multiphase preparations which consist of a lipophilic phase and an aqueous 
phase.  
Lipophilic creams have the lipophilic phase as a continuous phase. They generally 
contain water -in-oil emulsifiers such as wool alcohols, sorbitan esters and monoglycerides.                                                                                                      
                  
58 
 
Hydrophilic creams have the aqueous phase as the continuous phase. They contain oil -
in-water emulsifiers such as sodium or trolamine soaps, sulfated fatty alcohols, polysorbates 
and polyoxyl fatty acid and fatty alcohol esters, optionally combined with wat er-in-oil 
emulsifiers.  
 
  
Gels 
Gels consist of liquids which are gelled by means of suitable gelling agents. 
Lipophilic gels (oleogels) are preparations whose bases usually consist of liquid 
paraffin with polyethylene or fatty oils which are gelled with colloidal silica or aluminium or 
zinc soaps.  
Hydrophilic gels (hydrogels) are preparations whose bases usually consist of water, 
glycerol or propylene glycol, gelled with suitable gelling agents such as poloxamers, starch, cellulose derivatives, carbomers an d magnesium aluminum silicates.  
  
Pastes  
Pastes are semi -solid preparations for cutaneous application which contain large 
proportions of solids which are finely dispersed in the base.  
  
Poultices  
Poultices consist of a hydrophilic heat -storing base in which solid or liquid active 
substances are dispersed. They are usually distributed thickly on a suitable dressing and heated 
before application to the skin. 
  
 Medical wound dressings  
Medical wound dressings are flexible preparations which contain 1 or more active 
ingredients. They should be applied to the skin. They are designed to keep the active 
ingredient(s) in close contact with the skin so that they can be absorbed slowly or act as protective or keratolytic agents.  
 
                                                                                                      
                  
59 
 
Cutaneous patches  
Cutaneous patc hes are flexible preparations which contain 1 or more active ingredients. 
They should be applied to the skin. They are designed to keep the active substance(s) in close 
contact with the skin so that it (they) can act locally.  
  
 
FOAMS, MEDICINAL (Musci med icate)  
 
Medical foams are preparations which consist of large amounts of gas which are 
dispersed in a liquid which generally contains one or more active ingredients, a surfactant 
which ensures their formation, and various other auxiliaries. Medical foams a re generally 
intended for application to the skin or mucous membranes. Medical foams are normally formed at the time of administration from a liquid preparation in a pressure vessel. The container is equipped with a device consisting of a valve and a push- button suitable for delivering the foam. 
Tests: Relative foam density; duration of expansion.  
  
PHARMACEUTICAL PREPARATIONS UNDER PRESSURE (Praeparationes 
pharmaceuticae in vasis cum pressu)  
Pressurised  pharmaceutical preparations are, as a rule, multi -dose preparations which 
are presented in special containers under the pressure of a gas and are frequently equipped with a metering valve and contain one or more active ingredients. The preparations are re leased 
from the container if a suitable valve is provided in the form of an aerosol (dispersion of solid 
or liquid particles in a gas, the size of the particles being adapted to the intended use) or a liquid 
or semi -solid jet such as a foam. The pressure f or the release is generated by suitable 
propellants. 
The preparations are intended for local application to the skin or to mucous membranes 
of various body orifices or for inhalation. Pressurised pharmaceutical preparations are provided with a dispensing device suitable for the intended use. Pharmaceutical preparations under pressure, which are intended for use on severely injured skin or large open wounds, are sterile and correspond to the sterility test. It is also possible to use suitable auxiliaries, for example 
solvents, solubilisers, emulsifiers, suspending agents and lubricants for the valve, in order to 
prevent clogging.  
Pharmaceutical preparations under pressure can have the following components.                                                                                                     
                  
60 
 
Propellant. The propellant gases are either gases liq uefied under pressure or compressed 
gases or low -boiling liquids. Liquid gases are, for example, fluorinated hydrocarbons and 
hydrocarbons of low molecular weight (such as propane and butane). Compressed gases are, 
for example, carbon dioxide, nitrogen and nitrous oxide.  Mixtures of these propellant gases 
can be used to obtain optimum solution properties and desirable pressure, discharge and spray 
properties.  
Containers. The containers are sealed and resistant to internal pressure and can consist 
of metal,  glass, plastic or combinations of these materials. They are compatible with their 
content. Glass containers are protected with a plastic coating.  
Spraying device. The valve holds the container tightly closed when not in use and 
regulates the supply of the  contents during use. The spraying properties are influenced by the 
type of spraying device, in particular by the dimensions, the number and the position of the 
openings. Some valves offer a continuous unlocking, others (dosing valves) deliver a defined product quantity with each valve actuation. 
The various valve materials that come into contact with the contents are compatible 
with them.  
  
PREPARATIONS FOR INHALATION (Inhalanda)  
Inhalation preparations are liquid, semi -solid or solid preparations intended to be 
administered to the lungs as vapours or aerosols in order to obtain a local or systemic effect. 
They contain one or more active compounds which can be dissolved or dispersed in a suitable vehicle.  
Preparations for inhalation may contain propellant gases, cosolvents, diluents, 
antimicrobial preservatives, carriers, solubilisers and stabilisers, etc., depending on the type of preparation. These excipients do not impair the functions of the mucous membrane of the respiratory tract or its cilia.  
Suspensi ons and emulsions are readily dispersible during shaking and remain 
sufficiently stable to be able to deliver the correct dose. 
Inhalation preparations are supplied in multi -dose or single -dose containers. When 
supplied in pressure vessels, they meet the r equirements of the Pressurised Pharmaceutical 
Preparations monograph.  
Preparations intended to be administered as aerosols (dispersions of solid or liquid 
particles in a gas) shall be administered by one of the following means:  
- a nebuliser;

- an inhaler (pressurised metered dose inhaler, unpressurised metered dose inhaler or 
powder inhaler).  
Several categories of inhalers can be distinguished:  
- preparations intended to be converted into vapour;  
- liquid preparations for nebulisation;  
- pressurised inhal ation dosage preparations;  
- unpressurised preparations with dosing for inhalation;  
- inhalation powder.  
If the preparation contains an antimicrobial preservative, the efficacy of the 
preservative chosen shall be demonstrated to the satisfaction of the com petent authority. A 
suitable test method is reported in the general chapter “Effectiveness of antimicrobial 
preservation”. In addition, the preparation should have the “microbiological quality of non-sterile pharmaceutical preparations and substances for p harmaceutical purposes”, as described 
in the chapter of Pharm. Eur. 
The uniformity of the delivered dose of a multi -dose inhaler must be ensured within a 
product (intrainhaler) and between products (interinhaler). In the label should be reported  
- the dose  delivered or, if justified and approved (e.g., if the dose has been fixed as a 
dose or as a pre- dosed dose), the dose or pre -dosed dose;  
- if applicable, the number of deliveries from the inhaler to provide the recommended 
minimum dose;  
- the number of deliveries per inhaler.  
  
Preparations to be converted into vapour  
Preparations which are intended to be converted into steam are liquids, s olutions, 
suspensions, emulsions or semisolid or solid preparations. They are usually added to hot water and the generated steam is inhaled. 
 
Liquid preparations for nebulisation 
Liquid preparations for nebulisation are solutions, suspensions or emulsions which are 
intended to be converted into aerosols by nebulisers. Liquid aerosol preparations in 
concentrated form are diluted to the prescribed volume with the prescribed liquid before use.                                                                                                     
                  
62 
 
Liquid preparations for nebulisation can also be prepared from powd ers by reconstitution in 
the prescribed liquid. The pH of liquid aerosol preparations shall not be less than 3 and not 
more than 10.  
Liquid nebulising preparations supplied in multi -dose containers may contain a suitable 
antimicrobial preservative in an ap propriate concentration, unless the preparation itself has 
sufficient antimicrobial properties.  
Otherwise, these preparations do not contain an antimicrobial preservative and, if the 
preparation itself does not have sufficient antimicrobial properties, the y are sterile and are 
supplied in containers which prevent microbial contamination of the contents during storage 
and use.  
Finally, liquid aerosol preparations supplied in single -dose containers are sterile and 
free from preservatives, unless otherwise jus tified and permitted.  
Nebulisers are devices that convert liquids into aerosols by means of high- pressure 
gases, ultrasonic vibrations, extrusion through a network or other processes. They make it possible to inhale the dose with a suitable rate of release  of active compound over a prolonged 
period of time with successive inhalations and with a particle size which makes it possible for 
the preparation to be deposited in the lungs. Nebulisers may be breath- triggered or use other 
means to synchronise or modif y the nebuliser operation with the patient's breathing.  
Tests include: uniformity of dosage units, uniformity of contents, uniformity of mass 
and aerodynamic assessment of nebulised aerosols  
  
 Pressurised dosage formulations for inhalation 
Pressurised met ering agents for inhalation are solutions, suspensions or emulsions 
which are supplied in containers with a metering valve and which are kept under pressure with (a) suitable propellants which can also act as solvents. 
The dose delivered is the dose delive red by the inhaler. For some preparations, the dose 
has been set as a metered dose. The metered dose is determined by adding the amount deposited in the inhaler to the delivered dose. It can also be determined directly. 
Tests shall include: uniformity of d ose delivered, for preparations containing more than 
one active substance, testing for uniformity of dose delivered for each active substance, dose 
of particulate matter, number of deliveries per inhaler
